attributes.title: Physical Stock Take
attributes.description:
•    A physical inventory count was conducted at the branch on 23rd June 2025. The main objective of this exercise was to assess the effectiveness of inventory controls by physically verifying stock levels against system records ensuring accurate reporting, supporting inventory transparency and reinforcing stock accuracy. This process also aimed to highlight any discrepancies that may require corrective action.
•    The physical stock balances were consistent with the book balances, except for the following discrepancies:
a)    Bread stock had a variance of -112.5 pieces(A deduction was raised to the foreman on 23/06/2025, S/No 50251) 
b)    Packing materials had cumulative variance of -507 pieces,
c)    Brown Flour +12.37kgs
d)    White flour had -11.68kgs,
e)    Wheat bran had a variance of+4.53kgs
The stock findings are illustrated in the summary below:
attributes.recommendation:
•    Branch management should enhance supervision and monitoring of yield recording immediately after each mixing process.
•    In addition, stock control measures at the branch should be reinforced to prevent undocumented bread movements, misuse, or possible pilferage of key items particularly bread and polybags.
attributes.effect: The negative variances in bread stock and packing materials suggest weaknesses in inventory supervision and control. These variances could be due to poor yield management, inaccurate postings, wastage, or even stock theft. If not addressed, the branch may continue facing unexplained losses and reduced inventory accuracy.

value:
•    We will implement stricter follow-up measures for stock management. Special attention will be given to items such as bread and polybags, where we have observed significant variances.
•    Tighter controls, including close monitoring and cross-checking during production will help ensure that the expected yield is consistently achieved, especially for the items showing the largest variances.
•    We have identified a lack of close supervision during production. This issue will be addressed promptly to improve overall accountability

•    I will tighten controls of  both raw materials and finished products by making sure shift wise stocks and handovers are done correctly and well supervised by the branch manager.
•    The noted variations for both polybags and bread have been recovered where by bread stocks difference was due to excess damages not accounted for.

•    In prior audit dated 28th April 2025                                                                
a)    Polybags had a variance of +20 pieces
b)    The finished product had a variance of -37 pieces.
c)    White flour had a surplus of 3.63kgs
d)    Crates had nil balance.
e)    Other stock items had negligible variances.
A physical stock count was done on 23rd June 2025 to compare physical balances against system records.
Minor discrepancies in items like bread and packaging materials were noted, indicating possible pilferage or poor supervision.
Operations/Production Department
To confirm inventory accuracy and assess stock control effectiveness.

attributes.title: Bread weights.
attributes.description:
•    A weight check was conducted on the bread produced and packed at the branch to ensure compliance with the KEBS standard weight for all bread types distributed to the market.
•    The weight compliance check revealed that the 400g Sandwich (57%), 800g Naivas (43%), and 600g Naivas (33%) varieties had the highest proportions of underweight loaves, indicating poor weight control in these lines. Overweight percentages were relatively low across all varieties with the highest in 600g Bw at 36%.
•    Overweight percentages were generally low across all varieties, with the highest recorded in 800g Naivas (13%) and 600g (11%), suggesting slight over-portioning in some batches. These variances highlight the need for consistent monitoring of dough dividing and weighing processes during production.
•    The table below illustrates the findings:
attributes.recommendation:
Branch management should ensure all dividing machines are calibrated regularly and that dough weights meet the required pre-baking standards at the branch.
•     Weight verification at the packing stage should be reinforced to ensure that only bread meeting the required weight standards is dispatched to the market. 
•    Appropriate actions should be taken promptly for any underweight loaves identified.
attributes.effect:
•    Consistently distributing underweight loaves risks triggering customer dissatisfaction, complaints and potential loss of trust, especially from key clients such as Naivas. In a highly competitive market, this could seriously impact the brand’s reputation.
•    Overweight instances, though less frequent, contribute to unnecessary use of ingredients, increasing production costs and potentially affecting weight consistency in other varieties.
•    Non-compliance with KEBS weight standards exposes the company to possible regulatory action, reputational harm and financial penalties all of which could impact long-term business sustainability.

value:
•    We will ensure that slicers verify bread weights before packing and strictly follow the designated dividing ranges.
•    This will be achieved through continuous supervision and monitoring by the responsible staff at all times.

•    The noted underweights are due to lack of close production process follow up leading to over proofing of dough and being baked without steam.
•    I have had meetings with all branch supervisors and manager and discussed on the system operating procedure to be adhered to in order to make sure no issues with bread weights and stocks.

•    In a prior audit report, under weights were mostly observed as follows from transfers from other branches
a)    400g Long-73%,
b)    600g Bw-77%,
c)    800g Bt-55%,
•    Own branch production
a)    400g-10%,
b)    400g Naivas brown-15%,
c)    600g Bt-33%.
d)    600g Bw-25%
Previous
Bread weights were checked against KEBS standards for compliance.
Significant underweight loaves were found in some varieties, especially 400g Sandwich, highlighting poor production oversight.
To verify if bread produced meets regulatory weight specifications.

attributes.title: Bread damages analysis
attributes.description:
•    An assessment of bread damages was conducted at the branch for the period between 24th May and 23rd June 2025 to determine whether production adhered to the set quality control standards. The objective was to evaluate compliance with the allowable damage limits 0.2% of total production for production-related damages and 0.5% of total sales for market-related damages.
•    The review showed that market-related damages stood at 0.75% of total sales, surpassing the acceptable threshold of 0.50%. Similarly, production-related damages were recorded at 0.263% of total production, exceeding the permissible limit of 0.20% as outlined below:
attributes.recommendation:
Production teams must implement strict quality checks during baking and supervisors should closely monitor baking times, ensure proper greasing and handling of tins in order to control  damage rates per shift.
•    Sales crew should be held directly accountable for bread rotation and order accuracy at the outlet level. This will likely minimize intentional over-ordering which contributes can contribute to expiry issue continuously been noted at the branch.
attributes.effect:
•    The introduction of new baking tins has been identified as a contributing factor to the rise in production damages, weight inconsistencies and slower baking times. While the tins are expected to stabilize with continued use, the current inefficiencies continue to impact quality control.
•    Additionally, market-related damages were mainly caused by expiry issues, indicating potential challenges in stock rotation or  demand forecasting

value:
•    The recent introduction of new baking tins has contributed to an increase in product damages.
•    However, production is being carried out with full awareness of this factor. 
•    The tins are expected to perform better over time as they season with use.
•    Currently, they slow down the baking process due to longer baking times and have also been linked to weight inconsistencies.
•    Major contributing factor of market damages is expiry issues

•    We received new tins for 400gm ct   in April and this has led to high rate of production damages.
•    The tins are now ok and promise the production damages will be within the set limit or below.
•    On market damages, this is  due to expired bread from supermarkets hence we have got no controls over the ordering levels or market trend.

•    In a prior audit report dated 28th April 2025 ;
a)    Production damages rate was 0.304 % of total production,
b)    Market damages rate stood at 0.87% of total sales inclusive of supermarket returns.
Previous
Damaged bread was assessed to evaluate quality control during production and market handling.
Both types of damages exceeded limits, mostly due to new tins and expiry issues, indicating need for better stock and quality control.
Operations/Production Department
To compare actual damages against acceptable limits of 0.2% (production) and 0.5% (market).

attributes.title: Damages sent to Ingredients’ Balance Analysis
attributes.description:
•    An audit verification was conducted on 23rd June 2025 to ensure that all damaged bread reported as transferred to the Ingredients Department was either physically available or accurately recorded, in line with established procedures.
•    The verification covered the period from 24th May 2025 to 23rd June 2025. During the review, a discrepancy was noted between the expected quantity and the actual physical stock of damaged bread, as summarized below:
attributes.recommendation:
•    It is important to conduct periodic, real-time reconciliations to track and ensure that all damaged bread is accurately recorded before discrepancies accumulate over time.
•    This should include recording all damages in the designated manager’s book, clearly stating the source and reason for each entry to eliminate untraceable or unexplained damages.
attributes.effect:
•    This discrepancy translates to poor documentation or misclassification of damages, possible pilferage, misuse, or inaccurate weighing and recording of bread waste.
•    If not addressed, such variances could lead to ongoing losses, reduced accountability and compromised inventory accuracy, ultimately impacting cost management and operational transparency.

value:
•    It is important to conduct periodic, real-time reconciliations to track and ensure that all damaged bread is accurately recorded before discrepancies accumulate over time.
•    This should include recording all damages in the designated manager’s book, clearly stating the source and reason for each entry to eliminate untraceable or unexplained damages.

The noted excess damages are due to un accounted production damages  and this has been addressed through meeting with all branch supervisors and manager to improve on controls and transparency in branch sops.
•    In the previous audit from 1st March to 23rd April 2025, it was noted a negligible variance of +14.60 kg, equivalent to approximately 36.50 loaves.
Previous
A review was conducted to reconcile damaged bread reported and transferred to the Ingredients Department.
A variance of 155.5kg was noted, implying poor documentation or possible pilferage.
Operations/Production Department
To ensure completeness and accuracy of damage records.

attributes.title: Mixing chart Analysis
attributes.description:
•    The objective of this test was to review the mixing chart records, both shift-wise and summarized, for the period between 24th May and 23rd June 2025. The primary focus was to evaluate the branch’s Utto oil usage, average yield and any occurrences of remixes as outlined below:
a)    The Utto consumption was at1 unit per bag implying a ration of bags to utto unit of 1:1
b)    The average yield for the reviewed period was 191.52 loaves per bag.
c)    Average production was 104.81 bags per day representing 85.70% of target achievement which is 122 bags as tabled below:
attributes.recommendation: •    Branch management should conduct daily reviews of actual production against set targets to promptly identify any shortfalls and implement practical solutions to address the underlying issues, thereby minimizing production disruptions.
attributes.effect: •    The branch achieved an average production target of 85.70%, which falls short of the expected daily output. Slower baking pace caused by new tins and occasional oven breakdowns have contributed to the underachievement of production targets.

value:
•    The branch experienced occasional oven breakdowns; repairs were carried out promptly.
•     The use of new baking tins ha, however slowed down the pace of production due to longer baking times, affecting our ability to consistently meet daily targets. 
•    We are putting in place appropriate measures and controls to improve efficiency and ensure production targets are achieved.

•    Average production is low due to market trend  whereby we usually have production  balances controls due to low sales.
•    Sales team are working on how to increase sales and am sure  this will direct enable branch capacity utilization.

•    Previous audit report dated 14th March 2025 indicated the following:
a)    Yield-191.54,
b)    Utto-1:1~ 100%,
c)    Average Prod. – 101.63 bags equivalent to 83% target attainment.
Previous
Mixing chart records were reviewed to assess utto oil usage, yield, and production volumes
Production target achievement was low (85.7%) due to new tins and oven issues, calling for more efficient planning.
Operations/Production Department
To evaluate yield per bag and production trends against targets.

attributes.title: Production Efficiency
attributes.description:
•    A review of production efficiency was carried out to determine whether production staff met their set output targets and to identify opportunities for improvement. The evaluation focused on workforce utilization, comparing actual output against expected performance and analysing the financial impact of any inefficiencies.
•    It was noted that the actual production efficiency achieved was 4.13 bags per worker, which is below the target benchmark of 4.3 bags per worker.
•    A summary of the audit findings is illustrated below:
attributes.recommendation:
•    The generator needs to be repaired or upgraded to ensure it can fully support the oven during production. It is important to follow up with KAF to resolve the issue quickly.
•    It is necessary also to re-evaluate workforce deployment against actual output needs, adjusting staffing levels accordingly to prevent overstaffing and related cost inefficiencies.
attributes.effect: •    Underperformance against the production target indicates possible inefficiencies in production planning, supervision, or equipment availability.

value:
•    The use of new tins contributed to reduced worker efficiency due to delays experienced during production.
•    Additionally, the generator was unable to support all ovens simultaneously, further impacting output. 
•    This generator issue has been reported to KAF and is currently pending resolution.

•    The production efficiency is below the set target and we are encouraging production team to put efforts in achieving the target.
•    Again i have encouraged all supervisors to make sure production process flow is well monitored to enable easy targets achievements.
•    Finally we have had issues with branch generator whenever there is no power supply from kplc we are forced to switch off one oven in the middle of shifts thus affecting efficiencies.

•    From prior audit dated 28th April 2025,It was noted that;
a)    Average production efficiency was 4.32 bags per production worker.
Production performance was analyzed to determine average output per worker.
Efficiency was below target (4.13 vs 4.3 bags/worker), leading to extra labor costs and highlighting process delays and generator issues.
Operations/Production Department
To evaluate staff utilization and identify inefficiencies.

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency
attributes.description:
•    The branch's use of human resources in the packaging section was assessed by reviewing packing efficiency specifically the number of crates packed per worker and comparing it to the branch's standard efficiency rate of 97 crates per worker.
a)    From 24th May to 23rd May 2025 the average packing efficiency was 87.58 crates per packer which falls short of the standard target of 97 crates per packer for the sampled period, as detailed in the table below.
attributes.effect:
•    Continued underperformance in packing efficiency indicates ineffective workforce utilization and possible gaps in staff training or supervision.
•    Lack of consistent achievement of the target suggests that existing measures are insufficient or not being fully enforced.

value: •    Since the number of packers hired exceeded the actual requirement, it's important to align staffing levels with real production demands. Ongoing evaluations of packing needs and workforce usage should be carried out to minimize excess labor costs while ensuring operational efficiency.

Slicing efficiency is noted to be below the set targets.

We frequently encourage packers to increase and improve in wrapping speed to make sure targets of 97 crates is achieved or close to the target.
Packing data was reviewed to assess output per packer.
Packing efficiency was below target (87.58 vs 97 crates), resulting in overstaffing and additional costs.
Operations/Production Department
To measure the effectiveness of the packing workforce.

attributes.title: Mini shop Spot Check.
attributes.description:
•    A spot check was conducted at the Mini Shop on 25th June 2025 to verify that all bread intended for sale was properly recorded and that the sales figures aligned with the balances received through the designated pay bill number, as the Mini Shop operates on a cashless basis
•    We confirmed that all sales recorded up to the time of the spot check were accurately accounted for. In addition, the physical stock of bread including all loadings and top-ups (excluding sales) was found to be in order.
•    However, there was a discrepancy of KSh 85.5, with the adjusted M-Pesa balance falling short of the expected sales revenue, as detailed below:
attributes.recommendation: •    Branch management should ensure that daily reconciliation of sales versus M-Pesa collections is consistently performed at the close of business, with any discrepancies flagged and corrective action taken.
attributes.effect:
•    The identified discrepancy of KSh 85.3 between expected sales and the adjusted M-Pesa balance suggests potential issues such as lapses in real-time recording or reconciliation of mobile payments.
•    It may also indicate weak internal controls around minishop transactions, making it difficult to detect and address customer underpayments promptly.

value: •    Conducting daily reconciliations at the end of each day helps monitor and manage minishop variances. We will work to strengthen the existing controls to ensure better accuracy and oversight.
•    Close monitoring of mini shop will be done to make sure no variances or malpractices leading to variations.
•    In previous audit report, all the sales done as at the time of the spot check had a variance of -69.07/= from the till account balance attributed short from unidentified customer
A spot check was done on 25th June 2025 at the mini shop to verify sales versus M-Pesa records.
A KSh 85.3 shortfall was noted, suggesting possible lapses in daily reconciliation.
Operations/Production Department
To confirm that mini shop sales were accurately recorded and reconciled.

attributes.title: Cash Verification.
attributes.description:
•    As part of routine controls, a cash audit was conducted to confirm that the physical cash on hand matched the recorded balances in the cash flow records. The audit also aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of current cash handling procedures.

•    The spot check revealed that cash balances were well-controlled, with a minimal variance of -1, which was attributed to change balances.
attributes.recommendation: •    Continue to monitor cash-flow records regularly to ensure consistency between the physical cash on hand and the recorded balances.
attributes.effect: •    The minimal variance of -1 indicates that cash management controls are largely effective, with only a slight difference.

value: •    The control in place is effective and thus  we shall maintain
•    Branch cashier is encouraged to maintain the trend.
A physical cash count was conducted to validate records.
A minimal variance of KSh 1 was noted, indicating strong controls.
Finance Department
To assess the effectiveness of cash handling and documentation.

attributes.title: Vehicles’ fuel consumption analysis
attributes.description:
•    A review of mileage records for all branch route vehicles was carried out for the period between 1st June and 24th June 2025.
•    The objective of the review was to assess whether fuel consumption for these vehicles complied with the approved standard rates, to ensure efficient use of resources.
•    Overall, fuel consumption for most routes was found to be consistent with the established standards. However, discrepancies were noted on the Mwingi and Tinganga routes. The vehicle on the Tinganga route has since been repaired (starter issue), but the Mwingi route vehicle is still pending resolution, as outlined
attributes.recommendation: •    Branch management to strengthen vehicle maintenance and monitoring protocols to ensure mechanical issues are identified and resolved promptly to avoid prolonged operational inefficiencies.
attributes.effect: •    Prolonged mechanical faults, if not addressed promptly, can affect route reliability, fleet performance, and overall cost control, undermining efforts to optimize resource utilization.

value: •    The existing fuel control measures will be reinforced and consistently maintained.

•    Fuel consumption is always well monitored and fuel issued as per the distance covered.
•    Starter faults leads to over consumption once not attended to in time and this has   been addressed to kaf.
•    In prior audit, it was noted that all the route vehicles’ fuel consumption was within the set standard
Fuel usage data for delivery vehicles was assessed for efficiency and compliance with set standards.
Most routes were within range, except Mwingi (starter issue). Repairs were recommended for affected vehicles.
Transport/Fleet Department
To ensure optimal fuel usage across routes.

attributes.title: Generator Fuel Consumption Analysis.
attributes.description:
•    We reviewed and evaluated the fuel consumption rates of the generators for the period from 1st June to 25th May 2025 to assess whether the generators were functioning efficiently and within the expected operational parameters.
•    Upon analysing the data, it was found to be reasonable and consistent with the operational standards for this time frame as shown below
attributes.recommendation: •    The existing controls are effective and should be strengthened to ensure fuel consumption remains within reasonable limits and that the physical fuel balance is accurately recorded.
attributes.effect: •    Maintaining accurate fuel usage records is essential for cost control, operational planning, and detecting potential inefficiencies or irregularities early.

value: •    The existing fuel control measures will be reinforced and consistently maintained.
•    Branch manager is encouraged to maintain the generator controls.

•    In prior audit, it was noted that the generator’s consumption was within the 20-30 L/Hr range. It was also noted that branch maintained physical fuel balances for the generator ranging between 50 to 120 Litres per month which was against the company policy of having zero fuel balance
Generator usage logs were reviewed for the month of June.
Consumption was within expected rates (20.34 L/hr), and controls were deemed effective.
Transport/Fleet Department
To ensure fuel consumption remained within acceptable limits.

attributes.title: Supermarket Returns.
attributes.description:
•    A review of market damages (supermarket returns) from 24th May to 23rd June 2025, was carried out to determine the causes of the returns.
•    A detailed summary of all customer supermarket returns is illustrated below,


 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

•    Torn Wrappers; mostly reported from Naivas, caused by poor-quality packing papers. Indicates packaging material issues or handling problems
•    Expired & Short expiry: Majorly from Naivas and County Supermarket and are caused by poor stock rotation and oversupply not aligned with sales demand.
•    Quality issues mainly from Naivas. Likely due to the use of new tins that may not yet be optimized, leading to product inconsistency.
attributes.recommendation: •    Sales team should work closely with retail partners to implement First-In, First-Out (FIFO) practices and prevent stock expiry. Supply quantities should be based on actual sales data, not fixed schedules.
attributes.effect: •    The branch is incurring increased costs due to product damage resulting from torn wrappers, expired stock and quality-related returns.

value:
•    Issues with torn wrappers and quality control will be carefully monitored to minimize their occurrence.
•    Furthermore, details on product expiry at the branch will be communicated to the sales team to effectively manage and control expiry-related concerns
•    I will do thorough quality checks to make sure the best quality is dispatched to the market hence minimizing or doing away with fresh returns.
Returns from supermarkets were analyzed by cause and volume.
Most returns were due to expiry, poor-quality wrappers, and quality inconsistency. Better packaging and forecasting needed.
Operations/Production Department
To understand reasons behind returned bread and address quality issues.

attributes.title: Debtors’ analysis.
attributes.description:
A review of the debtors' balances as of 24th June 2025 was carried out to identify any instances of outstanding debts or unresolved balances by route.
•    As per this date total pending debt balance from medium to high risk accounts totalled to Ksh 1,764,333.13.
•    It was observed that most routes had either zero balances or prepaid accounts. However, some clients still had outstanding balances and were not supplied the following day. Additionally, some institutions or clients appear to be dormant. Dormant institutions pose a higher risk, particularly because they do not have any security deposits in place, as detailed in the table below.
attributes.recommendation: •    The sales team should be directed to actively follow up with dormant accounts, potentially proposing payment plans to encourage early settlement, which will help improve collections and ensure uninterrupted bread supply.
attributes.effect: •    The presence of outstanding balances on several accounts, especially those marked as dormant poses a credit risk to the branch if it remain uncollected for a long time.

value: •    I will engage with the sales team and stress the importance of ensuring all outstanding debts are promptly recovered.
•    Sales representative is following up with dormant debts to be cleared.
•    In the previous audit dated 28th April 2025, the outstanding debt was KES 4,796,021
Outstanding customer balances were reviewed as of 24th June 2025.
A total of KSh 1.76M was pending, with several dormant institutions. Follow-up and recovery efforts were recommended.
Sales Department
To identify and manage dormant or overdue accounts.
